title: Inside the institutional ETH staking world with Alluvial CEO Mara Schmiedt

rawLines.text: [Music]
Hello and welcome to the cryptobe. My
name is Tim Copeland and I'm the head of
critic at block. Joining me today we
have Alivio CEO Marash. Welcome to the

show. How's it going?
 Thanks for having

me Tim.
 So before we get started just a
quick reminder that if you are hiring in
crypto, you should use campus. Out of
all your candidates, it will help you
pick out the real crypto natives. Head
to the block.co/campus
to get a threemonth free trial. Now
today's episode is focused on Ethereum
institutional Ethereum staking. So first
up just to set the scene what is

Aluvial? What does it do?
 Yeah so
Aluvial uh provides next generation
staking services for institutions large
scale enterprises. We integrate with
custodians exchanges different market
participants. Olivial is actually also
the development services company behind
the liquid collective which is the
leading institutional grade staking

standard in the market.
 Okay. So what
does that mean when it comes to liquid
collective? What does it mean to be the

standard in the market?
 We've developed
liquid collective um and this kind of
goes back to our origin story actually
and I think it's an interesting one to
share. Um we saw a perceived need in the
market particularly within the
institutional space um as it relates to
the liquid staking services that were
offered and available at the time. This
was around 2021 2022. I was actually at
Coinbase following the acquisition um of
Bison Trails which was one of the
leading sticking infrastructure
providers in the space and we were
really really excited at the time about
a lot of the innovation that was
happening in the space with things like
multi-operator orchestration and
providing better security measures as a
result of it. Liquid staking unlocking
additional utility for staked assets um
improvements in capital efficiency. But
one of the challenges that we ran into
at the time was really leveraging these
kinds of innovations and technologies in
a way that would work with the design
requirements that sophisticated and
regulated institutions have when it
comes to uh counterparty risk
assessments when it comes to um
compliance requirements on the KYC and
AML side um and being able to you know
seamlessly integrate these services into
their existing um custody or exchange
platforms. And so that was really the
beginning of liquid collective that was
developed um in conjunction with design
partners including Coinbase, Kraken and
Figment at the time um to really build
out a liquid staking standard that could
interoperate across different market
participants and enterprises in the
space uh to really accelerate adoption
in the institutional vertical. And when
you say for things like uh AML is it so
like if an individual wants to stake
through you as a provider you have to
make sure that they are fully like KYC

is is that what you mean by that?
 That's
right. The model looks quite similar to
USDC for example. So minting and
redemption so the deposit of ETH um in
the case of LS ETH which is the product
um they actually get screened through
platforms that already have provision
KYC IML requirements. So when you think
about onboarding through something like
Coinbase Exchange or Anchorage if you're
a custody client um market participants
already go through some of these checks
and balances and so the minting process
itself kind of mirrors the behaviors of
what you would see with something like
USDC. Once LS ETH is minted against the
state ETH position or in the case of
other products um then actually it's
permissionlessly tradable in the
ecosystem. You can use it in DeFi, you
can trade it permissionlessly. Um and so
that was really really important because
when you think about you know
institutional compliance requirements
one of the things that you know we
stumbled into was sort of this you know
concept of coingled assets and
understanding where assets are actually
coming from when market participants
interact but then also withdraw ETH from
these different solutions and protocols.
So why is it okay to have sort of
essentially like permissionless
movement of the liquid staking assets
when you have to like have such strict
procedures? uh during the sort of
onboarding and offboarding process. Is
that because you're not directly
interacting uh with the counterparties?
Yeah, it's a it's a really interesting
question. So, I think the the main
principle or the main uh principle of
concern and let's take just a
permissionless you know fully
permissionless minting and deposit model
as an example. Um when you deposit into
a permissionless protocol um and you
effectively withdraw ETH from it later,
you don't actually know whose ETH you're
getting back, right? because all of the
ETH that sits underneath it is fungeible
and so it makes it really hard to track
back you know if that ETH has in any way
interacted um in a way that would create
compliance issues internally for for
some of these regulated businesses. Now
the LST or the liquid staking token that
lives on top of that is really acts more
as a receipt or a proof of ownership of
the underlying staked assets and so
market participants are more freely able
to decide how and where they want to
transact with these once they're minted.
And I think that gives rise to many
different use cases, right? Where you on
one hand can onboard institutional
market participants to use these
products and and also leverage them both
in centralized and decentralized
marketplaces depending on their needs
and their and their wants. Um but it
also opens up a universe where you know
ordinary retail users can seamlessly
transact with these products in the

market.
 And how does how do you solve
that issue with the withdrawals? So any
minting um or deposit of ETH and any
withdrawal of ETH goes through any of
these what we call supported platforms.
These are platforms that have
effectively gone through um compliance
screening with our compliance partner at
Capgeemini. Um and so it's the same
mechanism. If you effectively take an LS
ETH receipt and you look to redeem it,
you're actually going to one of these
supported platforms to get ETH back. And
so that ensures the consistency um in
both the deposit and the redemption
flows. um and the access points through

which they're enabled.
 I see. So, you're
only withdrawing ETH from like a pool of
funds where you know all the ETH that
put that went into that pool was checked

on the way in.
 That's right.
 Okay, that
makes a lot of sense. So, yesterday you
announced a partnership between Liquid
Collective and Galaxy. Uh what's the

what's the collaboration there?
 Yeah, we
we're really excited to get that out and
it seems like great timing to cover that
today. Um we announced a holistic
partnership with uh Galaxy that covers a
number of different verticals um through
liquid collective. Galaxy is going to be
providing OTC support and also
collateral acceptance for LST um through
its trading desk. Galaxy is going to uh
be offering uh Liquid Collectives
products including the expansion of
certain products to Salana um to its
asset management clients and then Galaxy
is actually also joining Liquid
Collectives active set alongside
Blockdemon, Figment, uh Staked and
Blockdemon um to uh to provide node
operator services to the network. um
that actually follows on the back of
them being one of the founding members
of NORS, our node operator risk standard
that was developed in conjunction with I
think 12 or 13 different market
participants. Um and so we're quite
excited about that. I think in many ways
this also signals I think just a growing
institutional appetite for liquid
staking products in the market and I
think we're seeing a lot of that you
know movement happening now in the
staking space generally but then the
liquid staking space um specifically. So
we're really excited to see that. I
think um a lot of these things in the
end really rely on having fully
integrated suites of services that meet
you know collateral needs trading
demands the custody needs of um the
different market participants that you

know interact in the space.
 So when you
mentioned like Salena is this expanding
to Salena for the first time in this

respect?
 Yeah well stay tuned for more
um but we teased some of this
announcement as part of the
collaboration yesterday. Galaxy is going
to be a part of this expansion and we're
excited to announce more launch partners
as we get ready to take this product to

market.
 Do you think there's a lot of
like demand for institutional uh Salana
staking? I know there's obviously a lot
of locked Salana sort of that's going
around ever since the FTX estate. I had
a chat recently with AEXI which has
bought it for their balance sheet. Um so
it's just is there just a lot of demand
there? I think in general we're seeing a
growing demand for institutional staking
at large and I think that's true across
all networks. Um if you look at some of
these statistics but then also some of
the milestones that we're seeing in the
market. You have things like you know
ETH hitting all-time highs on on staked
assets on the network. I think that was

only yesterday
 and not in price.
 Yeah. U
not in price. Um not yet anyways. Um,
you have major industry giants like, you
know, Fidelity and Grayscale filing for
staking inclusions in the ETH ETFs. You
see filings for Salana ETFs that
hopefully will in uh include staking and
due course. Um, and of course you're
mentioning the corporate treasury
strategies, but I think we're seeing
there sort of a really early use case um
for what it could look like to have, you
know, a cryptobacked and denominated uh
treasury strategy where staking really
unlocks more treasury like um uh reward
rates uh for market participants and
those corporate treasuries as well. So I
think overall like it it seems like
we're sort of seeing holistic trends of
the institutional market coming on chain
participating on chain but also
leveraging you know the benefits that
proof ofstake networks provide
holistically when it comes to uh
unlocking reward rates and then more
particularly unlocking additional usage
and I think that's where liquid staking
tokens play a particular role um when
you think about you know standardized
asset management function or corporate
treasury function in the end you know
market participants will look for the
best risk adjusted returns. In some
ways, liquid staking tokens don't just
unlock, you know, seamless and in some
ways risk mitigated access to staking
rewards, but they actually also enable
and unlock liquidity and co
composability in other parts of the
ecosystem, including DeFi. And I think
that's where things start becoming
really interesting um to really unlock,
you know, the power that, you know,
these composable technologies enable.
What do you think of the trend of
companies adding um ETH to their balance
sheet? Like obviously there's a lot of
companies doing it with Bitcoin. You've
seen a few starting to do it with ETH.
Um although doesn't seem to be going too
well for Sharp Link.
So I think um I think this trend is is
really really interesting. I think one
thing that you know I tend to say is
that you know staking itself tends to be
overlooked and sort of its ability to
generate um fully uncorrelated you know
reward rates for market participants
that are not necessarily tied to things
like interest rates or monetary policies
um that are that are sort of nationbound
and I think that's going to become an
increasingly important factor as market
participants look for you know
diversified strategies but also
diversified income products um in the
market. I think that um ESPED and and
and the ETH treasury, but also other uh
treasury um strategies that we're seeing
sort of unlock in the market um
obviously unlock a very new interesting
component which is taking reward rates,
right? Um and I think that sort of
unlocks uh new opportunities for for
these corporate treasuries to get access
to that T- bill like um rate of return
um while contributing to network

security.
 Interesting. Do you think um
staking rewards could become definitely
more interesting if say like treasury

yields dropped?
 I would certainly think
so. Um, I think as we're s sort of
seeing this convergence and I think this
reminds me a little bit of, you know,
the really early days of when things
like the serenity spec got designed, you
know, I it felt like a lot of the design
parameters around the network um were
were really, you know, one happening in
a zero interest rate environment as a
starting point, but then also I think um
really self-contained in the way that
they, you know, architected uh certain
parameters particularly because taking
reward rates are directly tied to a
network security budget and so adjust
somewhat autonomously. I think that
gives rise to two interesting dynamics.
One, you know, as we see this
convergence between the cryptonative
market and you know the traditional
financial services markets sort of
converge, I think market participants
will more holistically look at you know
what the different rates of returns are
that are available in the market and
we'll make um allocation decisions
accordingly. And so as interest rates
are expected to continue coming down,
you know, you would expect that the
reward rates that are offered by proof
ofstake networks become increasingly
attractive. But I think to my earlier
point, I think there's there's sort of a
secondary piece to this, which is those
looking for uncorrelated rewards, right?
Um that are tied to staking that are
sort of separate from monetary policies
or inflation rates. Um I think that
starts becoming quite interesting as
sort of an alternative uh strategy for
those allocations as well.
Yeah, the um the sort of converging of
crypto and traffic definitely seems to
be a rapidly growing trend at the
moment. I mean, you're seeing exchanges
now starting to look to offer tokenized
stocks and you know, people are sort of
joking that we've now sort of almost
gone full circle back to back to Trapfi.

Like what do you make of this trend?
 I
feel like we're absolutely seeing this
convergence, right? you're seeing
cryptonnative platforms tokenizing stock
and then you're seeing traditional
financial services businesses, you know,
adopting cryptonnative assets and it
feels like these, you know, these things
are starting to really converge um I
think a lot more prominently than what
we've seen in the last couple of years.
It's it's kind of interesting. I some
way in in which I like to think about
this and sort of my personal
perspective, it feels a little bit like
we're moving along this curve from
incremental innovation like tokenized
stocks or real world assets if we want
to call them that to eventually having
you know truly onchain uh products and
solutions and I think you know um
obviously Ethereum Salana but also the
properties that they offer um through
staking is is going to be a big
component of that um and it feels like
we're slowly moving moving along this
adoption curve where we'll have truly
native you know internet native assets
and internet native yield um that is
getting unlocked as as these market
participants move along that adoption

curve
 and if we see a lot more adoption
of sort of uh traditional assets within
crypto do you think that will increase
the demand for the sort of services that
like offers for instance because you're
going to need to have similar risk
profile mitigation because it's all
especially especially when you're
dealing with traditional equities and
everything, but then they'll have to do
it in in a way that's compatible with

with with the blockchain.
 Yeah, for
sure. I mean, I think we're we're
definitely seeing uh a lot more
traction. I mean, even just across our
business when it comes to, you know, the
growth that we've seen in the last, you
know, call it two months even, um, since
the staking guidance now recently got
released by the SEC, we're seeing a lot
more of the particularly US market
unlock. I think that's going to be
another massive accelerant when you
think when you see things like staked
ETFs getting approved. Um I think in
reality a lot of these institutions will
look for very robust tooling gateways
and access points so they can
holistically package their services into
their existing businesses into their
distribution channels. I think the
things that you know we've learned and
and sort of servicing this market for
the last couple of years is that really
robust security, really robust
performance optimization, you know,
compliance focused design um and and
native qualified custody integrations
are all going to be really really
important aspects um of the types of
technologies that you know these
incumbent institutions will ultimately
leverage to provide these services to

their clients.
 What did you think about
the recent SEC guidance? Were you

surprised to see it come out?
 I was not
surprised to see it come out. Um, we
were excited. I guess it was probably
the right word. Um, it it did seem like
it was moving maybe even a little bit
faster than we had initially anticipated
internally at least, which is a good
signal. I think that's also a good
signal for some of the other topics that
are sort of on the agenda for coverage
like extending this guidance to
contemplate things like liquid staking
tokens or the inclusion of staking in
ETFs. Um so I think overall it's a very
very positive signal. Um I think that
you know in many ways it feels like
market participants are going to be
materially unlocked in offering these
services. Now if you think back to the
former administration and a lot of the
challenges and difficulties that came in
offering staking services under clear
regulatory format I think a lot of that
you know is going to serve as a as a
tailwind now for market participants
that want to offer that. I think one of
the important distinguishing factors in
the guidance that is just worth you know
sort of mentioning is you know staking
when it provides network security should
not be considered a security. Now
staking if framed as staking but
actually under the hood you know
resembling more like a fractional
reserve model or like a lending product
you know should be adequately classified
as that and and and has separate you
know investment contract analysis
attached to it and I think it's really
really important that we clearly
separate what these functions are what
distinguishes them um because ultimately
that drives the right consumer
protection um that I think we all want
to see you know uh clarified in the
market
Is there much difference between stake

ETH and liquid staking tokens?
 So I
think the the way that we think about
the analysis is um that liquid staking
tokens resemble proof of ownerships or
title of ownerships um and we really
truly view them as receipts. And so when
you think about the commodity space for
example and this is like a good analogy
and you have you know corn or you have
livestock you know in a warehouse um
when you're effectively trading in the
commodity space you're not actually
moving like the corn from one silo to
another. Um what you're doing is you're
actually trading um against the receipts
um of those warehouse bills or those
titles of ownership um that that
demonstrate that beneficial ownership
structure for the underlying commodity.
It's no different if that kind of
concept is applied you know um in in the
digital realm right ETH that's being
staked and a receipt that bene you know
that demonstrates that beneficial
ownership you know is sort of subject to
the same analysis and I think that's why
we have you know very very strong um
arguments for why LSTs is sort of that
enabling layer um shouldn't be
considered as securities either um so I
hope hopefully that answers that I think
you know we look at this more as you
know no separate asset a receipt on the
underlying um that can unlock material
you know benefits when it comes to
utilization uh collateralization other
things that are ultimately important in
a mature financial system uh for any
type of asset or any type of commodity
and um what do you think about the
growth of I guess both staked ETH and
liquid staking tokens as a whole I mean
you mentioned earlier that we've now hit

above 35 million ETH staked
 it feels a
little bit like we're at an inflection
point now I think in large because the
institution market large scale
businesses particularly retail platforms
have kind of had to sit on the sidelines
particularly in the US for the last
couple of years uh in offering these
products I think there's a reason why
we're starting to see you know stake to
amount ratios coming up and sort of
reaching all-time highs on a relative
basis I think a lot of that is driven by
the institutional market you're starting
to see much more institutional
participation in staking you see new
categories of market participants
corporate treasuries
Sovereign wealth funds, you know, coming
into the space and and starting to
leverage the opportunity that the
technology provides. When you look at
things like, you know, the ETF market
alone, you have what around $9 billion
um in the US ETFs um that is currently
not utilized, not staked. So the ratios
actually start looking quite material
when you start bringing in, you know,
the capital and distribution power that
we see in, you know, more traditional
financial markets. And so I think we
should expect that to trend up. I think
on Ethereum it's particularly
interesting because I think we have um
only about 30% of ETH stake today. And
so there's it feels like a long way to
go and sort of uh leveraging the
utilization on the network relative to
something like Salana where I think the
ratio is closer to 70% today.
And what do you think of the lawsuits or
the sort of like attack on staking in
the US? And obviously sort of Coinbase
has been a bit big target, but with that
you've seen Illinois and Alabama drop
their staking lawsuits against Coinbase.
Like do you think that's starting to
change? Is there is there promising uh
light there? Yeah, I mean I think that
look the the SEC staking guidance was a
massive, you know, step in the right
direction to clarify what technical
staking services are, what categorizes
them, and also what distinguishes them
from things that maybe look more like
lending programs, right? And I think
that was very, very important. Um, it
feels like we're in a very different
universe now than where we were maybe
even a couple of months ago. Um, and I
think that's ultimately going to be a
good thing, right, to unlock, you know,
participation. If you think about it, in
some ways, you know, market participants
that are unable to offer staking inside
of their products um are not going to be
rendered competitive in the global sort
of landscape of things, particularly if
you think about them already offering
services like holding their crypto,
using their crypto to support network uh
security and then also being able to
earn rewards on it. Kind of starts
feeling like table stakes uh in terms of
the services that I think we'll start
seeing uh a lot of these market players
offer. And how important is it do you
think for the ETFs to start offering

staking or to start including that?
 Very
important. I think the reality is that
you have jurisdictions like Canada and
Switzerland where staking has already
been approved for certain ETPs and ETFs.
Um I think again for US products to be
competitive they're they're going to
have to offer you know the inclusion of
staking in their solutions because you
know it's sort of a loss for the
investor not having access to these
reward rate. it actually renders these
products less competitive than just you
know uh staking your ETH if you have it
on your own balance sheet or through
another vehicle or asset manager and so
I think that's quite material if you
look at the what like $9 billion in AUM
that's managed in US ETFs and you take
the you know 3.1% reward rate on ETH
that's 280 million annualized in rewards
that are not getting paid out and then
are not being made and then are also not
securing the network right so I think it
ends up being quite material at sort of
the scale and size that we're looking at
in the markets, but I'm quite
optimistic, you know, based on where
things are heading um that we're not far
away from these things getting approved
for Ethereum and then fingers crossed

also hopefully for Salana soon.
 If you
ended up with sort of ETFs having a huge
amount of sort of staked ETH, would that
potentially give them like quite a large
control over the network to some degree?
I think this question comes up a like a
few times. I think um overall if you
look at the sort of centralization
trends um in network stake over the last
couple of years things have actually
continuously trended towards being more
decentralized and I'm not just speaking
about you know the node operator level
or the counterparty level but then also
like a couple of layers deeper if you
think about execution clients consensus
layer clients you know cloud providers
onrem that people are deploying against
so I think the trend has continuously
moved towards a more resilient a more
distributed and more decentralized um
supporting structure for staking. I
think more market participants, more
diverse market participants coming into
um the staking space is a good thing
right on a net basis to continue
diversifying the market players that you
know contribute but also to sort of pave
the way to mainstream adoption for the
technology at large. And for the ETFs,
it looks like they had about 19 days of
inflows before the recent sort of
geopolitical turmoil led to prices
falling and we've started seeing some

outflows again.
 Do you have any any
thoughts on the current state of the
market given the sort of re recent uh

political climate changes?
 Yeah, for
sure. I mean, I think we always try to f
find like, you know, the silver lining
in the data that we're seeing. I think
espot ETFs having significant inflows, I
think somewhere around 700 million in
the last month relative to Bitcoin
that's actually posted outflows. I think
those are important metrics to sort of
look for. Um and and and things like
where is the overall market
participation and staking um and and
sort of where does that trend out. So I
think these are important metrics. Um I
think there's sort of the price you know
participation action. I think that's
sort of secondary to that which I think
in large you know continues to be
heavily influenced by what's happening
in the macro environment and also the

geopolitical space at the moment.
 Okay.
And do you think it's a good sign to see
Truth Social for a Bitcoin and Ethereum

combo ETF?
 It feels a little bit like
we've had sort of the pendulum swing,
you know, from one direction to another.
I think as part of the the shift in the
administration, I think that comes with
good things like, you know, a very
serious SEC crypto task force, you know,
the passing of uh the Genius Act in and
the Senate. I think there's very very
positive momentum for crypto at large,
stable coin regulation, clarity on
staking guidance and all of these
things, you know, together. I think when
where the pendulum maybe swings far is
sort of the the the current you know um
political appetite particularly in the
US to sort of push the boundaries on you
know what you know what the involvement
might be within the administration
offering and scaling some of these
products themselves and so I think we'll
we'll see probably a recalibration on
that. I think right now it's helpful for
the ecosystem to to be able to innovate
to be able to grow fast to capitalize on
the market opportunity. Um and I think
hopefully we'll sort of find the right
pendulum swing of where you know things
need to be and how they need to be
regulated at some point um to ensure
that you know consumers and investors
are are in a good position and protected

ultimately
 and what really unlocks the
next level uh for staking
I think broad crypto adoption in general
right like to me it's like staking is
like the pattern that you see from like
when you get people to hold uh crypto
the next question that they'll start
asking is what can I do with it Right.
And then staking sort of falls naturally
into the cycle of okay, I can stake it.
I can trade it. Eventually, I can
actually use it. And that's where DeFi
and sort of that connectivity starts
becoming really interesting. The more
market participants that hold crypto,
the more market participants that are
able to access crypto, I think the
bigger the universe or the, you know,
total surface area of of market that,
you know, can be served through that.
And I think it's a little bit analogous
to saying, you know, the more um bank
accounts people have, the more savings
accounts they will have, the more access
to these kinds of products and services
will be important and useful for them.
And so to me, everything feels like sort
of a rot market catalyst. I think if we
think about the adoption of where crypto
is at and how we get, you know, crypto
usage into the hands of like everyday
people um as they're on ramping through,
you know, stable coin products or uh

cryptonative products in the market.
 All
right. broader broader crypto adoption
it is.
Um, cool. Well, that is all we have time
for today. Uh, I want to thank Mara for
joining this episode and as a reminder,
Unus works tirelessly to get you
accurate, informed crypto news. If you
want to stay ahead, read the blog.
Thanks and see you next time.
[Music]

cleanText:
[Music]
Hello and welcome to The Crypto Beat. My name is Tim Copeland, and I'm the head of critic at The Block. Joining me today, we have Mara Schmiedt, Alluvial CEO. Welcome to the show. How's it going?
Thanks for having me, Tim.
So, before we get started, just a quick reminder that if you are hiring in Crypto, you should use Campus. Out of all your candidates, it will help you pick out the real Crypto natives. Head to theblock.co/campus to get a three-month free trial. Now, today's episode is focused on Ethereum institutional Ethereum staking. So, first up, just to set the scene, what is Alluvial? What does it do?
Yeah, so Alluvial uh provides next-generation staking services for institutions and large-scale enterprises. We integrate with custodians, exchanges, and different market participants. Alluvial is actually also the development services company behind Liquid Collective, which is the leading institutional-grade staking standard in the market.
Okay. So what does that mean when it comes to Liquid Collective? What does it mean to be the standard in the market?
We've developed Liquid Collective, um, and this kind of goes back to our origin story, actually, and I think it's an interesting one to share. Um, we saw a perceived need in the market, particularly within the institutional space, um, as it relates to the liquid staking services that were offered and available at the time. This was around 2021, 2022. I was actually at Coinbase following the acquisition, um, of Bison Trails, which was one of the leading staking infrastructure providers in the space, and we were really, really excited at the time about a lot of the innovation that was happening in the space with things like multi-operator orchestration and providing better security measures as a result of it. Liquid staking unlocking additional utility for staked assets, um, improvements in capital efficiency. But one of the challenges that we ran into at the time was really leveraging these kinds of innovations and technologies in a way that would work with the design requirements that sophisticated and regulated institutions have when it comes to uh counterparty risk assessments, when it comes to um compliance requirements on the KYC and AML side, um, and being able to, you know, seamlessly integrate these services into their existing, um, custody or exchange platforms. And so that was really the beginning of Liquid Collective that was developed, um, in conjunction with design partners including Coinbase, Kraken, and Figment at the time, um, to really build out a liquid staking standard that could interoperate across different market participants and enterprises in the space, uh, to really accelerate adoption in the institutional vertical. And when you say for things like uh AML, is it so like if an individual wants to stake through you as a provider, you have to make sure that they are fully like KYC? Is is that what you mean by that?
That's right. The model looks quite similar to USDC, for example. So, minting and redemption, so the deposit of ETH, um, in the case of LS ETH, which is the product, um, they actually get screened through platforms that already have provision KYC AML requirements. So when you think about onboarding through something like Coinbase Exchange or Anchorage if you're a custody client, um, market participants already go through some of these checks and balances, and so the minting process itself kind of mirrors the behaviors of what you would see with something like USDC. Once LS ETH is minted against the state ETH position or in the case of other products, um, then actually it's permissionlessly tradable in the ecosystem. You can use it in DeFi, you can trade it permissionlessly. Um, and so that was really, really important because when you think about, you know, institutional compliance requirements, one of the things that, you know, we stumbled into was sort of this, you know, concept of comingled assets and understanding where assets are actually coming from when market participants interact, but then also withdraw ETH from these different solutions and protocols.
So why is it okay to have sort of essentially like permissionless movement of the liquid staking assets when you have to like have such strict procedures uh during the sort of onboarding and offboarding process? Is that because you're not directly interacting uh with the counterparties?
Yeah, it's a, it's a really interesting question. So, I think the the main principle or the main uh principle of concern, and let's take just a permissionless, you know, fully permissionless minting and deposit model as an example. Um, when you deposit into a permissionless protocol, um, and you effectively withdraw ETH from it later, you don't actually know whose ETH you're getting back, right? Because all of the ETH that sits underneath it is fungible, and so it makes it really hard to track back, you know, if that ETH has in any way interacted, um, in a way that would create compliance issues internally for for some of these regulated businesses. Now, the LST or the liquid staking token that lives on top of that is really acts more as a receipt or a proof of ownership of the underlying staked assets, and so market participants are more freely able to decide how and where they want to transact with these once they're minted. And I think that gives rise to many different use cases, right? Where you on one hand can onboard institutional market participants to use these products and and also leverage them both in centralized and decentralized marketplaces depending on their needs and their and their wants. Um, but it also opens up a universe where, you know, ordinary retail users can seamlessly transact with these products in the market.
And how does how do you solve that issue with the withdrawals? So any minting um or deposit of ETH and any withdrawal of ETH goes through any of these what we call supported platforms. These are platforms that have effectively gone through um compliance screening with our compliance partner at Capgemini. Um, and so it's the same mechanism. If you effectively take an LS ETH receipt and you look to redeem it, you're actually going to one of these supported platforms to get ETH back. And so that ensures the consistency um in both the deposit and the redemption flows, um, and the access points through which they're enabled.
I see. So, you're only withdrawing ETH from like a pool of funds where you know all the ETH that put that went into that pool was checked on the way in.
That's right.
Okay, that makes a lot of sense. So, yesterday you announced a partnership between Liquid Collective and Galaxy. Uh, what's the what's the collaboration there?
Yeah, we we're really excited to get that out, and it seems like great timing to cover that today. Um, we announced a holistic partnership with uh Galaxy that covers a number of different verticals, um, through Liquid Collective. Galaxy is going to be providing OTC support and also collateral acceptance for LST, um, through its trading desk. Galaxy is going to uh be offering uh Liquid Collectives products, including the expansion of certain products to Solana, um, to its asset management clients, and then Galaxy is actually also joining Liquid Collectives active set alongside Blockdaemon, Figment, uh Staked, and Blockdaemon, um, to uh to provide node operator services to the network. Um, that actually follows on the back of them being one of the founding members of NORS, our node operator risk standard that was developed in conjunction with, I think, 12 or 13 different market participants. Um, and so we're quite excited about that. I think in many ways this also signals, I think, just a growing institutional appetite for liquid staking products in the market, and I think we're seeing a lot of that, you know, movement happening now in the staking space generally, but then the liquid staking space, um, specifically. So we're really excited to see that. I think, um, a lot of these things in the end really rely on having fully integrated suites of services that meet, you know, collateral needs, trading demands, the custody needs of um the different market participants that you know, interact in the space.
So when you mentioned like Solana, is this expanding to Solana for the first time in this respect?
Yeah, well, stay tuned for more, um, but we teased some of this announcement as part of the collaboration yesterday. Galaxy is going to be a part of this expansion, and we're excited to announce more launch partners as we get ready to take this product to market.
Do you think there's a lot of like demand for institutional uh Solana staking? I know there's obviously a lot of locked Solana sort of that's going around ever since the FTX estate. I had a chat recently with AEXI, which has bought it for their balance sheet. Um, so it's just is there just a lot of demand there? I think in general, we're seeing a growing demand for institutional staking at large, and I think that's true across all networks. Um, if you look at some of these statistics, but then also some of the milestones that we're seeing in the market. You have things like, you know, ETH hitting all-time highs on on staked assets on the network. I think that was only yesterday
and not in price.
Yeah. U, not in price. Um, not yet, anyways. Um, you have major industry giants like, you know, Fidelity and Grayscale filing for staking inclusions in the ETH ETFs. You see filings for Solana ETFs that hopefully will in uh include staking and due course. Um, and of course, you're mentioning the corporate treasury strategies, but I think we're seeing there sort of a really early use case um for what it could look like to have, you know, a Crypto-backed and denominated uh treasury strategy where staking really unlocks more treasury-like um uh reward rates uh for market participants and those corporate treasuries as well. So I think overall, like it it seems like we're sort of seeing holistic trends of the institutional market coming on chain, participating on chain, but also leveraging, you know, the benefits that proof of stake networks provide holistically when it comes to uh unlocking reward rates and then more particularly unlocking additional usage, and I think that's where liquid staking tokens play a particular role, um, when you think about, you know, standardized asset management function or corporate treasury function. In the end, you know, market participants will look for the best risk-adjusted returns. In some ways, liquid staking tokens don't just unlock, you know, seamless and in some ways risk-mitigated access to staking rewards, but they actually also enable and unlock liquidity and composability in other parts of the ecosystem, including DeFi. And I think that's where things start becoming really interesting, um, to really unlock, you know, the power that, you know, these composable technologies enable.
What do you think of the trend of companies adding um ETH to their balance sheet? Like obviously there's a lot of companies doing it with Bitcoin. You've seen a few starting to do it with ETH. Um, although doesn't seem to be going too well for Sharp Link.
So I think um I think this trend is is really, really interesting. I think one thing that, you know, I tend to say is that, you know, staking itself tends to be overlooked and sort of its ability to generate um fully uncorrelated, you know, reward rates for market participants that are not necessarily tied to things like interest rates or monetary policies, um, that are that are sort of nation-bound, and I think that's going to become an increasingly important factor as market participants look for, you know, diversified strategies, but also diversified income products, um, in the market. I think that um ESPED and and and the ETH treasury, but also other uh treasury um strategies that we're seeing sort of unlock in the market, um, obviously unlock a very new interesting component, which is taking reward rates, right? Um, and I think that sort of unlocks uh new opportunities for for these corporate treasuries to get access to that T-bill-like um rate of return, um, while contributing to network security.
Interesting. Do you think um staking rewards could become definitely more interesting if say like treasury yields dropped?
I would certainly think so. Um, I think as we're sort of seeing this convergence, and I think this reminds me a little bit of, you know, the really early days of when things like the Serenity spec got designed, you know, I it felt like a lot of the design parameters around the network um were were really, you know, one happening in a zero-interest-rate environment as a starting point, but then also I think um really self-contained in the way that they, you know, architected uh certain parameters, particularly because taking reward rates are directly tied to a network security budget and so adjust somewhat autonomously. I think that gives rise to two interesting dynamics. One, you know, as we see this convergence between the Crypto-native market and, you know, the traditional financial services markets sort of converge, I think market participants will more holistically look at, you know, what the different rates of returns are that are available in the market and we'll make um allocation decisions accordingly. And so as interest rates are expected to continue coming down, you know, you would expect that the reward rates that are offered by proof of stake networks become increasingly attractive. But I think to my earlier point, I think there's there's sort of a secondary piece to this, which is those looking for uncorrelated rewards, right? Um, that are tied to staking that are sort of separate from monetary policies or inflation rates. Um, I think that starts becoming quite interesting as sort of an alternative uh strategy for those allocations as well.
Yeah, the um the sort of converging of Crypto and TradFi definitely seems to be a rapidly growing trend at the moment. I mean, you're seeing exchanges now starting to look to offer tokenized stocks, and you know, people are sort of joking that we've now sort of almost gone full circle back to back to TradFi. Like what do you make of this trend?
I feel like we're absolutely seeing this convergence, right? You're seeing Crypto-native platforms tokenizing stock, and then you're seeing traditional financial services businesses, you know, adopting Crypto-native assets, and it feels like these, you know, these things are starting to really converge, um, I think a lot more prominently than what we've seen in the last couple of years. It's it's kind of interesting. I some way in in which I like to think about this and sort of my personal perspective, it feels a little bit like we're moving along this curve from incremental innovation like tokenized stocks or real-world assets, if we want to call them that, to eventually having, you know, truly on-chain uh products and solutions, and I think, you know, um, obviously Ethereum, Solana, but also the properties that they offer um through staking is is going to be a big component of that, um, and it feels like we're slowly moving moving along this adoption curve where we'll have truly native, you know, internet-native assets and internet-native yield, um, that is getting unlocked as as these market participants move along that adoption curve.
And if we see a lot more adoption of sort of uh traditional assets within Crypto, do you think that will increase the demand for the sort of services that like offers, for instance, because you're going to need to have similar risk profile mitigation because it's all especially especially when you're dealing with traditional equities and everything, but then they'll have to do it in in a way that's compatible with with with the blockchain.
Yeah, for sure. I mean, I


I think we're definitely seeing a lot more traction.
I mean, even just across our business when it comes to, you know, the growth that we've seen in the last, you know, call it two months even, um, since the staking guidance now recently got released by the SEC, we're seeing a lot more of the particularly US market unlock.
I think that's going to be another massive accelerant when you see things like staked ETFs getting approved.
Um, I think in reality a lot of these institutions will look for very robust tooling, gateways, and access points so they can holistically package their services into their existing businesses, into their distribution channels.
I think the things that, you know, we've learned and and sort of servicing this market for the last couple of years is that really robust security, really robust performance optimization, you know, compliance-focused design, um, and native qualified custody integrations are all going to be really, really important aspects, um, of the types of technologies that, you know, these incumbent institutions will ultimately leverage to provide these services to their clients.

What did you think about the recent SEC guidance?
Were you surprised to see it come out?
I was not surprised to see it come out.
Um, we were excited.
I guess that was probably the right word.
Um, it did seem like it was moving maybe even a little bit faster than we had initially anticipated internally at least, which is a good signal.
I think that's also a good signal for some of the other topics that are sort of on the agenda for coverage, like extending this guidance to contemplate things like Liquid Staking Tokens or the inclusion of staking in ETFs.
Um, so I think overall it's a very, very positive signal.
Um, I think that, you know, in many ways, it feels like market participants are going to be materially unlocked in offering these services.
Now, if you think back to the former administration and a lot of the challenges and difficulties that came in offering staking services under clear regulatory format, I think a lot of that, you know, is going to serve as a tailwind now for market participants that want to offer that.
I think one of the important distinguishing factors in the guidance that is just worth, you know, sort of mentioning is, you know, staking when it provides network security should not be considered a security.
Now, staking if framed as staking, but actually under the hood, you know, resembling more like a fractional reserve model or like a lending product, you know, should be adequately classified as that and and has separate, you know, investment contract analysis attached to it.
And I think it's really, really important that we clearly separate what these functions are, what distinguishes them, um, because ultimately that drives the right consumer protection, um, that I think we all want to see, you know, uh, clarified in the market.

Is there much difference between stake ETH and Liquid Staking Tokens?
So I think the way that we think about the analysis is, um, that Liquid Staking Tokens resemble proofs of ownerships or title of ownerships, um, and we really truly view them as receipts.
And so when you think about the commodity space, for example, and this is like a good analogy, and you have, you know, corn or you have livestock, you know, in a warehouse, um, when you're effectively trading in the commodity space, you're not actually moving like the corn from one silo to another.
Um, what you're doing is you're actually trading, um, against the receipts, um, of those warehouse bills or those titles of ownership, um, that that demonstrate that beneficial ownership structure for the underlying commodity.
It's no different if that kind of concept is applied, you know, um, in the digital realm, right?
ETH that's being staked and a receipt that bene, you know, that demonstrates that beneficial ownership, you know, is sort of subject to the same analysis.
And I think that's why we have, you know, very, very strong, um, arguments for why LSTs is sort of that enabling layer, um, shouldn't be considered as securities either.
Um, so I hope, hopefully that answers that.
I think, you know, we look at this more as, you know, no separate asset, a receipt on the underlying, um, that can unlock material, you know, benefits when it comes to utilization, uh, collateralization, other things that are ultimately important in a mature financial system, uh, for any type of asset or any type of commodity.

And, um, what do you think about the growth of, I guess, both staked ETH and Liquid Staking Tokens as a whole?
I mean, you mentioned earlier that we've now hit above 35 million ETH staked.
It feels a little bit like we're at an inflection point now, I think in large because the institutional market, large-scale businesses, particularly retail platforms, have kind of had to sit on the sidelines, particularly in the US, for the last couple of years, uh, in offering these products.
I think there's a reason why we're starting to see, you know, stake to amount ratios coming up and sort of reaching all-time highs on a relative basis.
I think a lot of that is driven by the institutional market.
You're starting to see much more institutional participation in staking.
You see new categories of market participants, corporate treasuries, sovereign wealth funds, you know, coming into the space and and starting to leverage the opportunity that the technology provides.
When you look at things like, you know, the ETF market alone, you have what, around $9 billion, um, in the US ETFs, um, that is currently not utilized, not staked.
So the ratios actually start looking quite material when you start bringing in, you know, the capital and distribution power that we see in, you know, more traditional financial markets.
And so I think we should expect that to trend up.
I think on Ethereum it's particularly interesting because I think we have, um, only about 30% of ETH staked today.
And so there's, it feels like a long way to go and sort of, uh, leveraging the utilization on the network relative to something like Solana, where I think the ratio is closer to 70% today.

And what do you think of the lawsuits or the sort of like attack on staking in the US?
And obviously, sort of Coinbase has been a bit big target, but with that, you've seen Illinois and Alabama drop their staking lawsuits against Coinbase.
Like, do you think that's starting to change?
Is there, is there promising, uh, light there?
Yeah, I mean, I think that, look, the SEC staking guidance was a massive, you know, step in the right direction to clarify what technical staking services are, what categorizes them, and also what distinguishes them from things that maybe look more like lending programs, right?
And I think that was very, very important.
Um, it feels like we're in a very different universe now than where we were maybe even a couple of months ago.
Um, and I think that's ultimately going to be a good thing, right, to unlock, you know, participation.
If you think about it, in some ways, you know, market participants that are unable to offer staking inside of their products, um, are not going to be rendered competitive in the global sort of landscape of things, particularly if you think about them already offering services like holding their crypto, using their crypto to support network, uh, security, and then also being able to earn rewards on it.
Kind of starts feeling like table stakes, uh, in terms of the services that I think we'll start seeing, uh, a lot of these market players offer.

And how important is it, do you think, for the ETFs to start offering staking or to start including that?
Very important.
I think the reality is that you have jurisdictions like Canada and Switzerland where staking has already been approved for certain ETPs and ETFs.
Um, I think again, for US products to be competitive, they're going to have to offer, you know, the inclusion of staking in their solutions because, you know, it's sort of a loss for the investor not having access to these reward rates.
It actually renders these products less competitive than just, you know, uh, staking your ETH if you have it on your own balance sheet or through another vehicle or asset manager.
And so I think that's quite material.
If you look at the what, like $9 billion in AUM that's managed in US ETFs and you take the, you know, 3.1% reward rate on ETH, that's 280 million annualized in rewards that are not getting paid out and then are not being made and then are also not securing the network, right?
So I think it ends up being quite material at sort of the scale and size that we're looking at in the markets, but I'm quite optimistic, you know, based on where things are heading, um, that we're not far away from these things getting approved for Ethereum and then fingers crossed also hopefully for Solana soon.

If you ended up with sort of ETFs having a huge amount of sort of staked ETH, would that potentially give them like quite a large control over the network to some degree?
I think this question comes up a like a few times.
I think, um, overall, if you look at the sort of centralization trends, um, in network stake over the last couple of years, things have actually continuously trended towards being more decentralized, and I'm not just speaking about, you know, the node operator level or the counterparty level, but then also like a couple of layers deeper if you think about execution clients, consensus layer clients, you know, cloud providers on-prem that people are deploying against.
So I think the trend has continuously moved towards a more resilient, a more distributed, and more decentralized, um, supporting structure for staking.
I think more market participants, more diverse market participants coming into, um, the staking space is a good thing, right, on a net basis to continue diversifying the market players that, you know, contribute, but also to sort of pave the way to mainstream adoption for the technology at large.

I can trade it.
